extendedIngredients.name: canned tomatoes
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 can (14-1/2 ounces) Italian diced tomatoes, undrained

recipes.title: Simple Italian Orange Roughy

winePairing.pairingText: Pinot Grigio, Gruener Veltliner, and Pinot Noir are great choices for Fish. Fish is as diverse as wine, so it's hard to pick wines that go with every fish. A crisp white wine, such as a pinot grigio or Grüner Veltliner, will suit any delicately flavored white fish. Meaty, strongly flavored fish such as salmon and tuna can even handle a light red wine, such as a pinot noir. One wine you could try is Attems Ramato Pinot Grigio. It has 4.4 out of 5 stars and a bottle costs about 14 dollars.

productMatches.title: Attems Ramato Pinot Grigio
productMatches.description: Pinot Grigio Ramato continues a tradition of the Republic of Venice, since “ramato”, or coppery, was the term referred to Pinot Grigio in contracts. A special vinification practice led to the use of this term: the must remains in contact with the skins for 24 hours and this practice gives the wine a very distinctive coppery hue. Attems Cupra Ramato boasts a rich, fruity bouquet, and opens full and weighty on the palate, with multi-faceted flavors.It is perfect when paired with fatty fish, with delicate or vegetable-based antipasti, the ideal companion to summer dishes, and is delicious as well as an aperitif.

recipes.instructions: Directions                                                                                Arrange fish fillets in an ungreased 13-in. x 9-in. baking dish. Sprinkle with lemon-pepper and salt. Cover with onion and celery. Top with tomatoes. Bake at 350° for 30-40 minutes or until fish flakes easily with a fork.                                        Yield: 4 servings.                                                                                                                         Originally published as Italian Orange Roughy in  Light & TastyFebruary/March 2004, p21                                                                                                                                                                                                        Nutritional Facts                                                                             1 fillet equals 145 calories, 1 g fat (0.55 g saturated fat), 34 mg cholesterol, 620 mg sodium, 7 g carbohydrate, 2 g fiber, 26 g protein. Diabetic Exchanges: 4 lean meat, 1 vegetable.                                                                                                                                                                    Print                                                                                    Add to Recipe Box                            Email a Friend

steps.step: Arrange fish fillets in an ungreased 13-in. x 9-in. baking dish. Sprinkle with lemon-pepper and salt. Cover with onion and celery. Top with tomatoes.
Bake at 350° for 30-40 minutes or until fish flakes easily with a fork.
